Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: An Investigation of Long Term Culture Contact and Accommodation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research is to understand how communities adapt to exposure to a new religious influence, how this is incorporated into a traditional extant world view and the material manifestations of this process. This issue is of central importance in the world today as lack of successful integration lies at the heart of conflicts in many regions of the world. Through the examination of the colonial process in which pre-hispanic New World cultures were exposed to Christianity through Spanish colonization it is possible to examine multi-religion interaction over extended periods of time.

Under the direction of Dr. Takeshi Inomata, Mr. Victor Castillo will conduct archaeological investigations at Chiantla Viejo, a small highland Maya settlement that transitioned to Spanish colonial rule during the 16th century. In order to address the mechanism of community survival in colonial settings, Castillo's research will study how the continued use of the plaza by the local community for public concentrations and massive rituals left room for negotiation between external innovations and traditional ritual practices. Combining the analysis of site layout, targeted excavations, and laboratory analyses, this project will provide a substantive dataset to evaluate the dimension of culture change as a political outcome during a critical transitional period for small local communities. CastilloÂ´s work will provide new grounds for addressing religious change beyond traditional models of acculturation and syncretism by studying a more complex and localized scenario of cultural interactions within the framework of colonialism. The investigations at Chiantla Viejo also integrates a constructive dialogue with the modern community surrounding the site since the place is treasured as the ancestral location of the modern town of Chiantla, thus raising awareness about the protection and preservation of the local archaeological patrimony. Ultimately, this work will present a more proximate and locally situated account of the ways in which native Maya groups responded to the colonial impact and how pre-Hispanic communities managed to transition successfully to colonial life and even outlasted the Spanish domination up to modern times.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Throughout history, many human groups have experienced conflicts when they get exposed to new religious influences. This is a significant problem today since the clash between religious worldviews is a source of conflict in many regions of the world. Our study at Chiantla Viejo, Guatemala, focused on studying the responses of a small Maya community to adapt to the imposition of a new religion during the Spanish conquest. 

Excavations revealed a short occupation at Chiantla Viejo at the very end of the Late Postclassic period (ca.  A.D. 1500 – 1550) as well as episodes of abandonment and reoccupation of the site during the first years of the Spanish colonial era. These episodes involved the destruction and remodeling of some structures and the building of a new ceremonial architectural complex of platforms in the plaza. The excavations at Chiantla Viejo revealed that the adoption of European material culture during the decades after the Spanish invasion of the Maya highlands was not a swift process. Although there is historical information that Maya leaders from this area of the highlands converted to Christianism as early as  A.D. 1537, the material evidence indicates that the decades after the Spanish conquest were times of intense revivalism of ancient architectural traditions. According to this evidence, the trajectories of religious conversion and integration of European artifacts into indigenous ritual contexts in the Maya highlands seem to diverge from patterns documented in other parts of the Maya area, such as northern Belize and the central lowlands of Petén.

Historical data indicates that Chiantla Viejo was burnt in A.D. 1530 as a result of the turmoil product of the Spanish presence in the region.  We found evidence of this fire in our excavations; consequently, the presence of a layer of burnt plaster in the plaza and on several buildings acted as a chronological marker to date all constructions and refurbishments that took place before and after the burning of the site. When the site was rebuilt after 1530, under colonial rule, constructors adopted ceremonial architectural layouts previously unknown at the site. However, these layouts were present in the abandoned site of Zaculeu, a nearby major ceremonial center that has been considered as a regional capital during Late Postclassic times (ca.  A.D. 1250 – 1525). Zaculeu, an impressive site with an occupation spanning one millennium, had been abandoned around A.D. 1525 when Spanish conquistadors arrived in the area.  The adoption of traditional ceremonial architectural arrangements from Zaculeu, nonetheless, happened in tumultuous times at Chiantla Viejo.  We found evidence that the small ceremonial platforms in the plaza were intermittently razed and rebuilt during a short period of time after the fire of 1530 but before the abandonment of the site ca. A.D. 1550. This evidence points out that the plaza acted as a scenario of ritual contention, but also indicates some sort of communal effort to build and destroy these platforms.

Archaeological excavations also revealed that after the final abandonment of the site, which can be dated historically around A.D. 1550 when the native community was relocated in a colonial reducción, Chiantla Viejo was re-visited during colonial times for the burying and scattering of human bones.

Results from this research suggest that small communities under intense stress due to the expansion of colonial powers and foreign worldviews engaged in revivalist movements. These movements could have offered frameworks for recognition of traditional ritual practices but also for innovation and even the adoption of new rituals in order to secure the survival of small communities in a changing world.  There is abundant ethnographic and ethnohistoric literature about religious revitalization movements in groups facing colonization, and the results coming from the research at Chiantla Viejo offer archaeological evidence to further expand on this issue.

Several Guatemalan archaeology students were trained during the research at Chiantla Viejo and they were exposed to field techniques as well as current theoretical debates in Maya archaeology.  This project also engaged in respectful interaction with the local community, which treasures the site as the ancestral location of the modern town.  Through archaeological evidence, this research answered some of the historical questions that locals have about the past of their own community. Several schools and many curious visitors were toured at our excavations, and they were introduced into the basics of archaeological research. A preliminary report has been submitted to the Institute of Anthropology and History and Guatemala and it has been made available for the local community as well. Preliminary results have been presented in the Annual Symposium of Archaeology in Guatemala and future journal articles, presentations, and a dissertation are in progress.  This is the first time archaeological research takes place in this area after several decades, and the results of the project have opened a new venue for future archaeological research in the region.
